page.title: 15LOCAL HISTORY-CHANGES
page.content: On 26th June Mr F. Luddington visited us at school to answer our questions about changes in the area.He was born in 1898 and lived at College Farm on Adams Lane.There were about 70 houses in Great Paxton at the beginning of the century,and Paxton Place was then the Vicarage.The school was one hall built in 1856 and a house for the headmistress,Miss Etchells.The other teachers were Miss Judd and Miss King.The 80 pupils sat on wooden benches to do reading,writing,arithmetic,woodwork and sewing.Everyone went home for lunch from 12:00 to 2:00pm.The village was very quiet,perhaps only one or two horses and carts passing each day.There were two pubs,The Bell and The Black Bull and one shop.Nearly everyone worked in the village.
